subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_008F_01C9D160.276D4D30
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

This is why with digital photos, you can't enlarge them without loosing res=
olution. You can go smaller, but not larger.

When you enlarge a digital ph=
oto, the photo gets stretched, but the same amount of pixels have to now fi=
ll in, so they get larger, which magnifies the pixelation. You end up with =
a blocky "lo-res" image. You can choose to have it "resample", but then you=
 get what RJ described, where the program looks at the existing pixels and =
add pixels that are an average of the surrounding pixels. So you still end =
up what a grainy, digital looking picture.

When saving a photo to a compre=
ssed format, such as jpeg, you actually loose data, or pixels. The program =
decides which data to drop to make the file smaller. Each time you open and=
 resave, you loose more data.The resolution gets worse and worse.

This is =
the same thing that happens with audio files, you loose data each time you =
save it to a compressed format.

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Rj=
 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
  Su=
bject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules






        Pixelization doesn'=
t clean-up the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a picture of a field o=
f flowers, and beginning to add levels or pixelization to the picture.  Soo=
n, you would not be able to tell there were flowers there at all.  You woul=
d see a lot of colored blocks.

        Or in the other direction, imagine =
you are looking at a competely randomize bunch of pixes on your screen: a c=
omplete screen of truely random static snow.  Pixelizing this, after a whil=
e, you would again start to see colored blocks.

        What's happening i=
s that it is processing an area of the image, taking (for instance) the ave=
rage value of that entire area, and replacing all the blocks in that area w=
ith the average.  In video processing, this would result in a field of mult=
i-colored flowers being replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish blo=
ck, with no resemblance to flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe replace=
 all the random pixels with another big greyish-bluish block.  If you did n=
ot know beforehand what the original picture was, you couldn't tell whether=
 your pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with =
clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

        It works the same with the so=
und files.  Taking something as complex as speech, and replacing frequencie=
s with their averages, loses the speech the farther you go, until you head =
strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the same to random static will eve=
ntually produce the same thing.  And random fluctuating square waves can so=
und a bit like speech - or at least, you could have fun sharing with each o=
ther what you thing they 'sound like'.





        --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Mi=
sty Dawn <bulletbabea@...> wrote:


          From: Misty Dawn <bulle=
tbabea@...>
          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
   =
       To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 9:=
29 AM


                I always save the whole file in wav format then do =
my clips as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis. 

                A=
s far as pixelization of non sounds/white noise whos to say that isnt being=
 manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a form of white noise. I seem to=
 remember some experiments done with blank tapes/film, no recording done ye=
t there were voices/images there. I find it all interesting.

             =
   Just a thought. Ok off to work now!
                Misty

             =
   --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


                 =
 From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Fi=
le uploading rules
                  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
         =
         Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 11:47 AM


                        Be =
a bit careful of formats like mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of t=
he sounds though.   While some formats (like wav) can store the audio very =
close to the way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress the file, and i=
n so doing lose some of the sonic details.  This may not be a big deal in m=
usic, where the audio is fairly clear to begin with.  But with sound source=
s with a lot of noise (like evps), this can not only obscure any real sound=
s, but pixelize non-sounds (like white noise) and make them start to sound =
like speech.

                        So mp3 might be good for sharing the =
data, once you've already formed an opinion based on an analysis of the wav=
 file.  But mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  It can lead to many =
false positives and misinterpretations.

                        --- On Sun=
, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                   =
       From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                          =
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                          To: E=
VP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                          Date: Sunday, May 10, 200=
9, 8:26 AM


                                Thanks =3D)

                 =
                You will get the hang of it. Kristen is right thats how you=
 save it. For most softwares its under save as or export as. If you still h=
ave trouble use one of the links I posted to help ya out.

                =
                Misty

                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09,=
 SnowfireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol. com> wrote:


                         =
       From: SnowfireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol. com>
                      =
          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                     =
           To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Dat=
e: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 2:14 AM


                                Ok, Mist=
y I'll take them out, this recording stuff is new to me.

                 =
               In a message dated 5/10/2009 1:13:01 A.M. Eastern Daylight T=
ime, bulletbabea@ yahoo.com writes:



                                Plea=
se do not upload wav format files here they will have to be removed. Our gr=
oup only has a very limited amount of space. Upload bigger files and mass a=
mount of files to your esnips.com accounts or elsewhere to be shared here u=
sing links. 

                                Misty
